dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse and 14-year-old Hank are walking through an airport Greece.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: So you got everything?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Mmm-hmmh.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You going to play video games the whole flight, or do you think you might actually crack a book?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Probably read some.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: If I write you an email, don't be scared to write me back, okay? It won't kill you to let your old man know what you're thinking about and what's going on, you know?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: If we want, we could try Skyping once a week or something.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: All right...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You got the drawings for your science deal?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, think so.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Alright, well they turned out great by the way. Like, really great.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Thanks. They've arrived at the concession stand. Hank grabs a cou of snacks. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is your computer charged?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What do you think's the first thing you're gonna do when you get home?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I dunno.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I really cherish this communication we have. You know, it's just - your answers are so...

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: (interrupting) What? Jesse is paying.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Just keep practicing the piano, okay? You're really good and they spend so much time at that school of yours... just remember that music is actually something you will use in your life. Right, and don't forget to - you want those sesame things, right? They're really good.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Right. (to cashier) Yassou. Here you go. Thank you. Okay. He gets the change and they head to the gate.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll probably make it over there in October, you know? Try to see you in that first recital and then hopefully catch a soccer game while I'm there. (to cashier) Efharisto. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might not even play soccer this year.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh, that'd be a big mistake. Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I'm not that good.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh, no, you're pretty good. You are.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I mean, I missed summer training camp, so the chances of me starting are minuscule.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, just tell the coach the situation - your dad lives in Europe, you really wanted to be there, blah blah blah. Blame me. My parents stink, but I'm really serious.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: But I'm not serious, Dad. I don't care that much.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Well, you don't have to decide right now. You know, just think about it. All I'm saying is that team sports are important, you know? They've arrived at the security line.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here we are. I love this airport, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: It's awesome.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know, it's cool, right? You excited about seeing your mom?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, and all my friends. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right. What about your boarding pass, passport...? Okay. You feel confident about making the connection?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, I've done this before.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but not with a tricky connection like this. Just remember, when you land, you stay in your seat. Somebody from the airline's going to come get you and take you to the gate, right?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: It's not a problem.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay. All right. Oh, boy. Well, looks like maybe we should just do this thing, huh? Okay. Come here. They hug.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm gonna do my best to make that recital, okay?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: You know, I wouldn't bother.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What makes you say that?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Look, I'm not being mean, but it'd be easier if you didn't come to the recital.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: It'd just be better if you visited on another weekend.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: But... I want to see you play.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Look, it's because Mom hates you so much. She'd be really stressed if you were there, and then it'd be tense for me. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  Jesse motions to the person behind him to go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We wouldn't have any time to hang out, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Don't worry about her, we'll figure that out, we can... Just don't want you to worry about it. You know? I mean... you know how much I miss you, right? Hank nods.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why do you think she still hates me so much?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I don't know. I think she hates Daniel more than she hates you. Hank playfully punches Jesse.

dialogues.speaker: HANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, don't worry about it. I'll figure something out. We should just do this though.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah. But I mean, is there anything I can do to help?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: But you know that I love you, right?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Right, okay.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. This has been the best summer of my life.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Yeah! Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, me too. See, I told you, I told you this whole Greece thing was going to be great.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: And it was. A final moment.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay. All right. I love you, pal.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: I love you too, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay, shake my hand. All, right, go.

dialogues.speaker: HANK
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Bye. See ya. (sighs) He goes into security. Jesse watches him walk away, and then slowly heads toward the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow Jesse back through the airport as he finds his to the parking lot, revealing Celine, standing outside of the car, talking on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: (speaking french) Oui, oui. (continues in french) Okay. As Jesse and Celine settle inside the car, the camera pan over toward two 6-year-old girls who are asleep in the ba seat. That's right, twins NINA and ELLA. They start drivi away from the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they hit the highway, Celine lowers her volume as she wraps up her conversation. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Okay. Bon. Trés bien. Merci. Oui, oui, Lucia. Au'voir. (hangs up, speaks french)

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: They voted against it.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What, the wind turbines?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Six months dealing with those people, they were all for it. Everyone agreed it was great for the region...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh. So what happened?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: ..-And now they've decided that they don't like the way it looks on that hill. It's ruining their view.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No, no, I thought it was a done deal.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It was! It practically was--

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Well, can--

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: That's what's so infuriating.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Can they do that?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. They've done it. That's it. It's over, fini.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, no, it's just so frustrating. I can't take it anymore. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.text: (beat) I'm gonna take that job with Remy.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No. No, you don't want to work for him.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: For the government?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Well, I think this government is different. We need laws. That's the only way anything is going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It's not the only way. You guys have been getting a lot of good work done.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Well, I've been thinking about it. This is the way to go.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay. Well then, let me remind you that you do not like that guy. The whole time you worked for him before, you complained about him constantly.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, yeah. He can be an asshole, but he gets things done. That's how I'm gonna be from now on--

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: A real bitch, okay? That's it.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay. Well every time I look at that guy, all I see is ambition. I mean, I'm sorry, I just don't trust him. The only reason he's going from non-profit to government is to have people kiss his ass. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care about him, okay?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: All right, and I think you're gonna be miserable, all right? Just with all that politicking and compromising--

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Whatever. I've made my decision. I'm tired of being the do-gooder that rolls a boulder up a hill and watches it roll down again.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Isn't he the guy that used to throw his pens at his assistant and stuff?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay, I should have taken this job a year ago. You know, and I was scared because of the amount of work, but I think it's the best opportunity ever and it's more money and... I'm doing it.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay. Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, I'm not sure of anything, okay?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: All right, all right--

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I mean, you know, what's gonna happen to everyone if I leave? Like Francoise, and I mean, they count on me. What do you think? Should I take it or not, should... Should I?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Ah, no, no, no, I don't have an opinion. I just don't want to see you rush into a decision because of this wind turbine crap.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No! It's not just that, okay? It's been stirring in me all summer...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Well, I know it has. I know. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  10.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: ..-And I should do it. And I'm doing it!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: All right then, just - then do it.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I'm doing it, all right? Oh, god. I wish things were simpler. I mean, if I leave I get fucked, if I stay I get fucked...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (laughs) There's always a catch.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, the world is fucked.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, baby.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Oh, god. We finally have a vacation and the girls are sick for the first two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Or the perfect son who lives a million miles away.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Or the love of your life can't clean up after himself or learn how to shave.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Who's that? You're not, you're not talking about Captain Clean-up over here, are you? You don't mean--

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Captain Clean-up! The one that's been missing in action all these years!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What did you expect at this point in your life, missy? Celine turns back to look at the twins. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.text: God! Oh, look at them; they're so cute! They look like conjoined twins! Oh my god, I gotta take a picture. She takes out her cell phone and takes a picture. reaches back for something he can't quite find.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Hey, did uh, did Ella finish that apple?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You're going to take food out of your child's mouth?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah. 11. Jesse Celine reaches back and grabs a half-eaten apple off the seat.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay. Well. It's all brown.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh, there's a spot here. He takes a bite from the green part of the apple. now filming him with the camera.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Ella - this is evidence of your father stealing food from you. If you become bulimic or anorexic, it is not my fault. Don't blame it all on your mother, okay?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Ella, this is a family apple. I'm teaching you the value of sharing. I love you honey.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Ohh, so sweet. You girls will remember this vacation very differently than we will.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: That's for sure. I see that with my mom. She remembers my childhood entirely differently than I do. Can you please stop filming me. Celine puts the phone away. Celine is Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  12.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: God. I love your mom. You're always so hard on her.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It's because you missed the fucked up years. You're just getting the good era.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: The "fucked up years." That reminds me, talking about fucked up... did I ever tell you the story of my little Cleopatra kitty? No? Okay, I think you would remember if I did. When I was a little girl I had this cat named Cleopatra and every spring she would jump the fence and get pregnant and always end up with a litter of exactly two kittens.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Two kitties?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Two kitties. Every time, every year, two cats. I mean it was just... amazing. Then one day, I was around 30 and I was having lunch with my Dad, I was remembering, mentioning little Cleopatra and he was like - ‘the hardest thing I ever had to do was to kill those cute little kittens'- and I was like WHAT? It turns out-- listen to this--there were sometimes up to 7 kittens in that litter--

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: But he would take five of them--

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: --Put them into a plastic bag with a bunch of ether.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (laughs) That's terrible. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.text: He had forgotten the lie he and my mom had told me as a kid.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: How did he decide which ones he wanted to kill?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Well, I actually asked him that. Did you take the fluffiest, cutest? He just started to cry.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Poor Daddy. They realize they're driving by some ancient ruins.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, we said we were going to stop. They wanted to see the ruins.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but should we?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Well, Ella really wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You know what, let's do this. On our way back to the airport we can catch them.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You know we won't.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, probably not.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: We'll be like, so long, ancient ruins! What's so great about you anyway? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca 13.

dialogues.text: Psh! Seen one, seen them all! Oh my god, we are shitty parents. We should have stopped.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Aw, it's okay.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It's culture. Come on, go back.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Ah, we gotta put some character in these kids somehow, you know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: We're teaching them a valuable lesson, you know. You snooze, you lose in this world.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: And when the girls are in rehab, recovering from ten years of addiction to coke and speed, they'll say, "oh, we just never felt comfortable going to sleep because our daddy always used to tell us, "you snooze, you lose." And that'll be your fault again.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (laughing) Okay, okay. Well, we are shitty parents.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Saying goodbye to Hank sucked.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Why, was he upset?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE

dialogues.text: Well, that's great! (MORE )

dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  15.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, I wouldn't worry too much about him. We spoke a bunch, and you know what his main concerns in life are?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Pimples and how girls perceive him. The apple doesn't fall far from the tree, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What do you mean? I'm not like that.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Oh, please!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE

dialogues.speaker: CELINE

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Women! I mean--I'm not complaining. I'm getting a lot of attention. But you never stop ogling girls.

dialogues.text: I don't ogle girls.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: (laughs) Well, I think... You know, Henry might have, you know.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: That little Melina girl.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I don't know. He had a crush but...

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Oh, are you kidding?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Why do you think he said it was the best summer of his life?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Because he and I had a good time together?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Jesse...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No, huh? So what, you think they... you think they what--

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE

dialogues.text: Yeah, they kissed! Yeah, yeah. Okay, I was sworn to secrecy but he told me. They kissed. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay. He told me he was worried - you know, concerned about the kissing. You know, tongue, no tongue.

dialogues.text: What, he asked you that?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah. But he was so - he was so cute. All nervous, all red, biting his cheek like when he was little. So cute.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Wow. So he and Melina were a real thing.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE

dialogues.speaker: CELINE

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You're so corny! Sometimes I'm just like -

dialogues.speaker: JESSE

dialogues.speaker: CELINE

dialogues.speaker: JESSE

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah, I do. It was you.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Oh, please. Like you were a virgin at twenty-three. I don't -

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay. Fine. Like I'm the first woman you ever fell in love with?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Pretty much. The first one I felt truly connected to. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: (beat) No, of course not.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh. No, I just - I thought I was.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It's okay, it's okay. It's nota big deal.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No? Okay. How old are you? Come on!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I'm forty-one and I have loved only you. A beat of silence, then they both laugh. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  19.

dialogues.text: You are so, so working on our little night, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Hell yeah. I've got a Trojan in my billfold and a rocket in my pocket.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE

dialogues.text: No, no, no, but I meant the hotel, later. I just, I'm not sure I want to go - Her phone rings. She picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hi, sweetie. Yeah. Oh, okay, okay, okay, okay. Well, well, it's fine. It's fine! Call me from London. Have a good flight. Bye. Jesse gestures for the phone, but she's already hung up.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: But - but -

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: They were telling them to turn everything off, they were about to take off and I asked him to call me from the plane; you know, I don't like when he flies. (a beat) What?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I don't - I dunno. I dunno. (sighs) I just don't think I can keep doing this. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  20.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Just every summer, every Christmas, you know, it's like -

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I know. It makes me ill every time.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It just wouldn't be so bad you know if I - like if we were sending him to boarding school or something. Just - I dunno. ...If his mom and I got along a little bit better.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I know. It's like we're sending him back across enemy lines.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know. It really hit me this time, you know? I mean, he's going to be a freshman in high school! Four more years and then he's gonna be on his own.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Well, maybe that's the good news. We only have four more years of this.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No, no, no. This is the crucial time. I just feel like I should be there for him. Like it's now or never, you know?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No. What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I guess I just thought somehow he'd end up living with us. Somewhere along the way, you know. Now time's going by so fast and here we are! It's high school, you know. There's girls... next thing you know it's college applications.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, you're right! Maybe it's time. I mean... I really think it's time. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  21.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just tell his mum all this and ask if he can come and live with us. He'd love it, we can put him in that bilingual -

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: That's never gonna happen, all right? She's never gonna give me one thing that she's not legally obligated to.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Do you want to call that lawyer again?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No. I don't like that guy. He's terrible.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Should I call his mother?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Uh, no. Please. Never again.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, I know.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Look, he doesn't even know how to throw a baseball.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Who cares?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: He just... he leads with his elbow. He throws like a girl.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: That's not your fault.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No, it is my fault. A father is supposed to teach you that.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay, he just doesn't like baseball does he? Who can blame him.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No, it's an example, okay? It's a metaphor for everything. He's turning fourteen and he needs his father. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  22.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Jesse, I'm not moving to Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Well, did I ask you to? Celine rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where'd that come from, huh? I'm just thinking out loud. I mean, this is the one thing I promised myself I would never do and I look up and I'm doing it.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Well... listen, you're a wonderful father. He loves the relationship you have, he loves the letters you send him and he -

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: He doesn't even read the letters that I send.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, of course he reads them; he just doesn't compliment the writing the way you want.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I just know that if I miss these years, they are never coming back.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Oh, my god.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: This is where it ends.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What're you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: This is how people start breaking up.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh, my god. What'd you just... you just jumped off a cliff. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  23.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, no. I'm marking this. This is the day you light the ticking bomb that will destroy our lives. Jesse laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah. Watch.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay. Well, first off, you don't light a ticking bomb, okay, you set it and it's a timer -

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Oh, okay, whatever! Whatever, okay.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: - That's why it ticks.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It has a timer. Well, you know what? It's ticking. Right now. And this is how it happens.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You're unhappy, you blame it on the other person, resentment grows, everything slowly rots and you break up. That's it.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You're just doing this to shut me up.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Not at all. Not at all!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know you are. That's what you're doing. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No-no-no-no. I'm actually surprised we lasted this long.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay, Okay. So here comes the hyperbole- Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  24.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: We were on parallel tracks for a while but now our tracks have crossed and I'm going west and you're going east. And believe me, this is how it happens. I've seen it, okay? Catherine Alexander -

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You're kidding, right? You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Well, no! I'm kidding. And I'm not. All right? (beat) Just - this is it. As Celine talks, the girls wake up. One of the girls, ELL groggily says:

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: How much longer to the ruins?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Oh, they were closed.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sweetie, you know what we decided, we're gonna catch them on the way back, when we're going to the airport.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: We'll leave early, right? Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: What happened to my apple?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Your apple. La pomme, elle etait fini, cette pomme. Right? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull up at a small store in a coastal fishing villag and start getting out of the car. Celine is speaking in French to the girls.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Give me the list.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I don't have it.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It's in your wallet.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: In your wallet.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay. He gets out his wallet and hands it to Celine. She pulls out the list instantly.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Voila! She turns to the girls.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm the General! Captain Nina, (tells her what to do in french)

dialogues.speaker: NINA
dialogues.text: Oui!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Who made you General?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: The General, okay?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Captain Ella, (tells her what to do in french) Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  26.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Oui!

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Private Clean-Up, you don't touch anything.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oui. D’accord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls up outside an estate by the shore. They get out and the girls sprint through the entryway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the patio outside the house, a soccer game is going on with Jesse and many other participants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a wonderful seating area, PATRICK listens to a story NATALIA is telling him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a small garden, Celine, Nina and Ella pick vegetables. Celine has a nice moment where she's just looking at her little girls in nature, engaged with the earth.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: The red one.

dialogues.speaker: ELLA
dialogues.text: Cela?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Trés bien... Okay. Pepper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse, PATRICK, and STEFANOS are relaxing at the far end the patio where there's a beautiful ocean view.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: I actually read them both. The first one is called THAT TIME, the second one is called THIS TIME.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: The first one is THIS TIME, the second one is THAT TIME. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  27.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: We've got a joke in our family that "This" brought us back together and "That" paid for our apartment.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: Well, it must be a little weird for Celine, man, the way she's in a book like that, no?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Why? I think she's gotten used to it.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: But the second one is sexy, man. When he misses the plane and they black out the windows and they have sex for days and days and days like there's no tomorrow. I mean wow, did you guys actually do that? Jesse shrugs his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You did that, uh?

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Have you read Jesse's third book? It's actually better than the first two.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It certainly took longer to write than the first two put together.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: No, the third one I didn't read. I mean, my wife gave it to me but it's just a little bit too long for me, man. Even the title is long. What's the title?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: "Temporary Cast Members of a Long Running But Little Seen Production of a Play Called Fleeting." Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  28.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: Well, exactly my point.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Ah, well, you're not alone. Everybody else thought it was too long.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: It's a better book. It's so much more ambitious. (in Greek) The first two were so so.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: (speaks Greek) Really? Do you think?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: No, he says he likes all the books. He does.. Jesse laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalia, Ariadni, and Celine are sitting at a table in th kitchen, chopping vegetables.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I mean, I love it here. This place is amazing. These tomatoes are so amazing. I can... I can smell them! They smell so good.

dialogues.speaker: ARIADNI
dialogues.text: Yeah, Patrick is very proud of them.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I know it's stupid but when we were about to leave Paris I was a little nervous to come here. And now that we're about to leave, I don't want to go.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIA
dialogues.text: Why were you nervous?

dialogues.speaker: ARIADNI
dialogues.text: Yeah, why was that? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  29.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I don't know. This place is so full of thousands of years of myth and tragedy and I thought something tragic was going to happen.

dialogues.speaker: NATALIA
dialogues.text: What, you thought the Minotaur was going to eat your children or something?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yes. Exactly. All three women laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back with the guys...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: All right, well, the whole time I've been here, I've been working on this idea about a group of different people with all these brain abnormalities. So the book would be like a day in their life from all their unique points of view, right? Like there's this older lady who has a condition that makes you feel like you're ina perpetual state of déja vu. Every single experience she has, she feels like she's had it before. I mean she can be sitting here with us, talking seemingly functional right? And in her head, she's thinking: Didn't he already say that? I mean; weren't we here yesterday having this exact same conversation.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: So just like Deja Vu.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, except all the time.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Right, that's the thing, right? Everything she takes in. Breakfast, a newspaper, a movie. She's convinced she's encountered it already. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  30.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: So that's a real condition?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's called persistent deja... It's real but I can't pronounce it. The men chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Then there's these two other characters with facial recognition extremes. Like there's this one guy and he can't recognize his wife of twenty years. He looks at himself in the mirror and he feels this disconnect with that man he's looking at. Then the other character is the opposite, middle-aged housewife with a categorical exacting memory of every face she's ever seen; so she lives in a big city but to her, it's a small town. Like, a taxi drives past and she thinks 'Oh, that's the driver who dropped me off at Place de Vosges three Christmases ago.' And some old lady walking on the street, she thinks; 'Oh, she sat two seats down from me on the Metro last year.' So, everyone she meets,to her feels intimate and connected.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: Well, I'm just like the first guy. Like I feel connected to nothing most of the time, man. We see Patrick's grandson, Achilles, and girlfriend, Anna come walking by, just from the beach. Anna slaps his butt playfully before heading indoors while Achilles joins the guys.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh, Achilles! Anna! Hey, you guys.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Hey, look at this kid. He's having the best summer of us all.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Hello, Pappou.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: So you were saying... there's three characters, right? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  31.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No, it's not just three characters, it's a whole group of people. It's like, I'm working on a chapter right now about a young Greek man named Achilles.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Well, he's named after you. And this guy is caught in a loop where all he sees is the transient nature of everything, right? Like he looks out to sea and thinks of the day it's gonna be dry and littered with fossils.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: Well... I dunno. It sounds a little pretentious to me.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Ah, no-no-no. It won't be pretentious, I promise. No, it's gonna be funny. Really funny. He picks up a book and he immediately wonders: Who's gonna be the last person to read this?

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: And that’s funny? All laugh.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Sometimes I kind of think like that.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: Well, okay, so he doesn't get excited about tits, cars, booze, nothing. He just thinks about death.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Well, not so much death, right? It's just like transformation, you know. Like he's seeing too far into the future.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: Okay. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  32.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: I like this idea for a novel. But you should add a character of an old man like me - a poor sap who can't remember what he had for breakfast, but he can still hear the song that was playing when Sheila Campbell danced topless on the bar at Jury's when he was 14 years old.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: That'll work.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: Okay. You have these people lost in time, right ok? But what's the connection? Are they going to have sex? Don't you need something like that?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It's not time that they're lost in, right? It's like perception. That's the deal. No, I'm thinking of setting the whole novel at a movie. Like, every character in some way comes in contact with the film 'On the Waterfront.' (to Achilles) Have you seen "On the Waterfront"? He's not sure until Stefanos tells him the Greek title.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Oh, with Brando!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah. Okay, well, the first chapter of the book is opening weekend, Times Square, 1954. That old lady, with perpetual deja vu walks into the matinee screening, right? Except the whole time she's thinking: haven't I already seen this?

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  33.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Right. And then another chapter is a 1979 Paris film studies class. Then we have a Kazan retrospective in Munich, 1993.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: Well, man, that is time. How is that not time?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's time but, it's more perception. You don't like it.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: I think it's going to be too long. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Well, I like it. Don't listen to him - he makes bicycles. Send it to me in galleys.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Will do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All five kids are playing a game together somewhere on th property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ariadni, Stefanos, and Celine are in the kitchen, prepari the meal.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: In France we stuff the tomatoes with tomatoes and the peppers with peppers.

dialogues.speaker: ARIADNI
dialogues.text: Oh, really? Because we use the same stuffing for both, because of the way it reacts differently, in terms of taste. Oh, and Celine, make sure you don't stuff them too much because of the way it overflows in the oven later and gets kind of nasty.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay okay, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: You're doing fine, Celine. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  34.

dialogues.speaker: ARIADNI
dialogues.text: And especially don't listen to Stefanos here because he's never made this dish before, or any other dish for that matter. He takes her knife.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: (Laughing) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: You know, I mean...

dialogues.speaker: ARIADNI AND STEFANOS
dialogues.text: (Yelling, Speaking Greek)

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: Let go of me, (Greek) Let go of me!

dialogues.speaker: ARIADNI
dialogues.text: (in Greek) Stefanos, why are you taking my knife? Stop stealing people's knives. Here is a knife perfectly good for what you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: (in Greek) Sweetie, I cannot cut with this little fucking knife.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Are you guys fighting, with knives? Okay, stop it! Stop fighting with knives.

dialogues.speaker: ARIADNI
dialogues.text: We're not fighting. We're negotiating. Anna enters the kitchen and goes over to the refrigerator

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay, negotiating, that's what you call it? Wow, (in French) Negotiating with knives. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  35.

dialogues.speaker: ARIADNI
dialogues.text: (in French) Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: (In French) Not bad.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: This is a system that we have.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Wow, so you found a system that works for you.

dialogues.speaker: ARIADNI
dialogues.text: Mm-hm.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I thought it was called a relationship. But I like "system", that's pretty good. That's ready, right? Ariadni walks over and takes a drag off his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: That's ready. Celine takes a platter of appetizers and begins to leave.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: (to Anna, in French) And you, what's your system? Anna gestures oral sex.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in French) What about this system? Celine puts her tongue between her fingers by her lips.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (in French) Not bad. Celine exits.

dialogues.speaker: STEFANOS
dialogues.text: We used to have that system. Anna laughs. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse leads the kids down the rock steps to the little pa of rocky beach under Patrick's house.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Not too far, you guys! We catch a nice moment where Jesse is looking out at the sea, and at the kids, soaking it all up. He checks a text and the moment is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now in the middle of their dinner, Jesse taps his wine gl and gets everyone's attention.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: All right, I don't want to let this meal go by without saying thank you to everyone. And especially you, Patrick. We had no idea what we were getting into these last six weeks. A letter arrives from the university, inviting us to the Southern Peloponnese of Greece, to the guest house of a great writer? ‘Sure, why not?' And then at the airport earlier today, Hank turns to me and he says this has been the greatest summer of his life.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: (Reacting)

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: And I have to say the same. So, thank you Patrick, and not just for what you have done for me and my family but for all the ways you've given back, all right. So, to Patrick!

dialogues.speaker: OTHERS
dialogues.text: To Patrick... Glasses clink.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Thank you, thank you, thank you. You know, when I first saw you at the airport I thought, 'No way a man dressed like that could be a man of letters.' Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  37.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: (Laughing)

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: But now, now I think I've learned your secret. We've had many great writers here over the past decade but never one who had a partner more interesting than themselves.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: (Reacting) Ohh. Oh. (Laughing)

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I keep telling you.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: And Celine, it's been so great to have you and your daughters' wonderful vitality around here, and I'm so happy you've been able to meet my dear friend, Natalia, who's husband Elias was like a brother to me.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: (to Patrick) I'm so sorry about the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: Don't worry. It's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know. I shouldn't have thrown those cherries-

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, I mean, really -

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It was my fault.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK/CELINE
dialogues.text: No, no. That's sweet of you.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: And Grandpa, thanks for including Anna and me this summer... because you know he usually puts me to work but when I bring Anna he lets me sit at the table of the grown-ups. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  38.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Welcome to the grownups table! Hear hear!

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: (to Anna) How long have you two been together?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Since last summer.

dialogues.speaker: ACHILLES
dialogues.text: We met one year ago in my last few days here with grandpa before I had to go back to Athens.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yeah, we met at my closing night cast party. I was doing Shakespeare at Epidavros...

dialogues.text: Well, when I think of Elias, what I miss the most about him is the way he used to lie down next to me at night. Sometimes his arm would stretch along my chest. Every time I do something, I think of what he would say: "Well its cold today, wear a scarf." But lately I've been forgetting little things. dialogues.speaker: NATALIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sometimes, I make myself remember every detail of his face - the exact color of his eyes, his lips, his teeth, the texture of his skin, his hair - that was all gone by the time he went. And sometimes, not always, but sometimes I can actually see him. It is as if a cloud moves away and there he is. I could almost touch him, but then the real world rushes in, and he vanishes again. For a while, I did this every morning, when the sun was not too bright outside because the sun somehow makes him vanish. He appears and he disappears like a sunrise or sunset, anything so ephemeral. Just like our life - we appear and we disappear and we are so important to some, but, we are just passing through.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: And when he's in his fifties the imaginary friend shows up again, right?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: With the hummingbird? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  57.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yes, that's the one.

dialogues.speaker: JESE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Oh, you like that one?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It's funny.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Remember that letter that you let me read that you wrote when you were twenty, to yourself at forty?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I remember the first sentence: Dear Forty-Year-Old Jesse, I hope you're not divorced.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, I didn't even remember that part. I meant all the other things in that letter...you were the same guy.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I mean, we always think we're evolving, but maybe we can't change that much.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You know how I think I've changed the most?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: When I was younger I just wanted time to speed up. You know?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Well. So I could be on my own. So I could be free from my parents and school and all that shit. You know? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  58.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just wanted to close my eyes and wake up and be an adult. And then I kind of feel like that all happened and I just want everything to slow down.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Hm... it's strange - I've always had this feeling, no matter where I am in my life, that it's either a memory or a dream.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know, you've always thought that. And me too, it's like, is this really my life? Like, is it happening right now?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It is.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know. Celine and Jesse laugh.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Every year I just seem to get a little bit more humbled and more overwhelmed about all the things I'm never going to know or understand.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: That's what I keep telling you. You know nothing!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know, I know! I'm coming around! Celine and Jesse laugh.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: But not knowing is not so bad. I mean, the point is to be looking, searching. To stay hungry, right?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know, it's true. I just wish it was a little easier.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: How do you mean? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  59.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Well, just to maintain a certain level of passion, you know? I mean it used to come so naturally. I remember when I was younger, me and all my writer friends, we just felt like we were doing something important, you know? Like this was our time.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: But you were all a bunch of arrogant little pricks, right?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No, we -

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Sounds like. (Laugh)

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: All right, maybe. I don't know, it just grew out of all this energy you know, this creativity or whatever ambitions people had. You know, I think you gotta be a little deluded to stay motivated.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Young men have this thing about comparing themselves all the time. They have all these signposts they judge themselves by. You used to do that all the time.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Do what? What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: With like: Rimbaud read this by seventeen, F. Scott Fitzgerald did this by thirty...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: And Balzac wrote a book before breakfast every day, so what the hell am I doing?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah. But women don't think that way as much.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You don't think so? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  60.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No. We have much less to compare ourselves to maybe. Most women who achieve anything in life, the first time you hear about them, they're in their 50's, because it was so hard for them to get any recognition before then. They struggle for 30 years or they raise kids and were stranded at home before they could finally do what they want. Actually, you know what? It's kind of freeing. We don't have to spend our lives comparing ourselves to Martin Luther King, Gandhi, Tolstoy...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (Laughing) Well, what about Joan of Arc, right? I mean, she was a teenager and she saved France. So...

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Who wants to be Joan of Arc, okay?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Forget France. She was burned at the stake and a virgin! Okay? Nothing I aspire to. What a great achievement!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (Laughing) Okay! All right, all right, all right. Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: (Laughs) Oh, god.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It's just so weird. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  61.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Oh, just this. Us. Walking, having a conversation...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh, I know.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: ..+. About something else than scheduling, food, work.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I mean, how long's it been since we just wandered around bullshitting?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Do you hear what I hear?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: The sea?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What, oh! No small feet. Nothing being knocked over, nothing we have to clean up, no injustices being done.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah. So when was the last time?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: When we had nowhere we had to be?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You remember walking around Luxembourg Gardens?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Do you? I used to kick your ass at ping pong on those concrete tables. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  62.

dialogues.text: Well, it's better than losing to a pregnant woman with twins.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Such a gentleman! Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (a beat) Hah-ha! You know what I think? I think its from the time we leave our parents house until we have kids - that's the only time your life is completely your own. You know I think I had about a decade of that. It was great. It was just like one long, flowing... a day, a week, a year, there wasn't much difference.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, I used to keep track of time through jobs and boyfriends and stuff like that. Now I can tell you every detail of the past seven years based on what was happening in the girls' lives.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE

dialogues.text: Yeah, I mean time's demarcated now...

dialogues.text: Oh, no... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  63.

dialogues.text: August 2009 - we were on vacation with your parents. Nina got the chicken pox first, quickly followed by Ella.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh, okay. Alright, wait - if I saw you on a train, okay, listen. I would lock eyes with you.

dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: And then I'd walk right up to you and I'd say, "Hey, baby. You are making me as horny as a billy goat in a briar patch." He grabs her ass.

dialogues.text: Stop it, that's disgusting! Billy goat. No, the truth is, you failed the test. And the fact is, you would not pick me up on a train. You wouldn't even notice me, a fat-assed middle-aged mom, losing her hair.

dialogues.text: Okay. (Laughing) Losing her hair?

dialogues.text: Yeah, that's me!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You set me up to fail. Honestly, you did.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay, true. True.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Alright? Alright? But in the real world, baldy, on game day when it mattered, I DID talk to you on a train. I did that, it was the best thing I ever did.

dialogues.text: Really? Look at the goats. Hello. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  65.

dialogues.text: It's true.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay. All right, okay. Okay!

dialogues.speaker: CELINE

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: All right, you know..

dialogues.text: No, no, no, no. Nothing like that alright? Well actually, it's kinda like that. My grandmother died.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm so sorry. Why didn't you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Ah, I know. Well, everybody's been expecting it. You know, she lived a long time, had a great life. She was ninety-six.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay. She didn't live much longer after your grandfather died, though.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No, barely a year. I mean the funny thing is, this woman was a frickin' saint.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: She was a nurse in the war, she took care of all of us, you know. I mean, she never said an unkind word about anybody.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Ah, I wish I'd met her.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No, it's okay, because by the end, you know, she just really wasn't into meeting new people. I mean after a lifetime of being sweet as pie - once grandpa died, she got kinda ornery. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  68.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE

dialogues.text: Fuck!

dialogues.text: Ugh!!!

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Will you be able to put up with me for another fifty-six more years? I need to know! Okay? 'Cause I don't know if I'm gonna be able to put up with you. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  69.

dialogues.text: It's crazy if you think about all the change they saw. I mean, when they met neither one of them had electricity. He used to take her to school on his horse, right?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE

dialogues.speaker: CELINE

dialogues.text: Yeah, obviously like you-know-who.

dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, of course, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: .+.- You know, tell him I was sorry... but I think I kind of screwed up. At some point I told him 'Hey Dad, you're an orphan now.' He didn't think that was funny.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE

dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess not. (MORE )

dialogues.text: I know. Well, he told me that my grandparents want to have a joint service. They want to have their ashes intermingled and be buried as one.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE

dialogues.speaker: JESSE

dialogues.text: (a beat) Oh! Look at this! Wow. This place sort of reminds me of this film I saw when I was a teenager. It was a black and white film from the 50s. I remember a couple walking through the ruins of Pompeii, looking at bodies that had been lying there for centuries. I remember the bodies caught in their sleep, still lovingly holding each other. I don't know why, sometimes I have this image in my mind when, you know, we're asleep and you hold me.

dialogues.text: (Laughing) Well... I don't know, it's not horrible. They had some bodies with little kids sleeping between them...

dialogues.text: Oh, that's nice!

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah! I guess I was young and a bit morbid - I mean at that age you romanticize the idea of dying with the person you love.

dialogues.text: Oh, no! Putain de merde, I blew it. Okay, if we're both 98 you can ask me again, but anytime sooner...Ehhnt! (Whispers) Sorry. They are walking by an old, tiny Chapel.

They like to paint with water on rock on a hot day so by the time they're done it's already evaporated. Celine notices all the icons have been subtly defaced. dialogues.speaker: EXT. WALK PART THREE- EVENING

dialogues.speaker: CELINE

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Right. Yeah. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  77.

dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh, listen, come on, come on. If we're ever going to truly know one another, I think we'd probably have to get to know ourselves better first.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE

dialogues.speaker: CELINE

dialogues.speaker: CELINE

dialogues.speaker: CELINE

dialogues.text: (Laughs) Well, I'm gonna try to make your dreams come true, babe. They arrive at the waterfront. The sun is now setting ove the ocean.
