dialogues.text: Well, moving to Chicago is pretty fucking dramatic to me.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I'm not saying we should move. I just want to talk about it. Can you be my friend for like two seconds so we can talk?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay, two seconds.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Alright. Do you remember that time that you were like 35 minutes late to pick the girls up from school and you were so stressed out because you knew they were out there in the playground wondering what the hell had happened to you. Okay, that is the way I feel all the time, you know like I fucked up. I mean, I left him behind and I just wanna go get him. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  94.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You always get like this when you drop him off. You're sad, so you start a fight. He's fine. He's a great kid. Okay? But the truth is, he doesn't need you the way he used to. You missed the opportunity to be with him everyday of his childhood, you just did. And you can cry about it but he's growing up. You're a great father in other ways. You got divorced, like millions of other people. Was it ideal? No. Listen, if in one month, you still want me to quit my job and give up everything I have ben working towards all these years, just ask me. But right now I feel the same way I always have. I would move back to the US if that diseased ex-wife of yours would give us joint custody. But every other weekend amounts to shit Jesse, that's less than thirty days a semester and I don't think it's worth it for us to change our entire lives over that kind of time.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know, you're right.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Right, right? See? I'm being the rational one.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh, it's just such a shitty position, you know? I mean Hank didn't do anything but he's the one getting kicked in the teeth.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: We all get dragged through our parents' lives. If it wasn't me, your marriage would have ended over something else and you know that.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Or even worse, he would have been raised by two miserable parents. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  95.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know. I just really fucked that up.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You mean you fucked up by moving to Paris to be with me?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No. That's not what I meant...

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I knew that was going to cost too much.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: That's not what I meant at all!

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I told you not to do it.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Stop it.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I moved to New York with you for two years and gave up everything, but I needed to be home to give birth to the twins because it was a complicated birth and I wanted to be with my mother. And you wanted it too!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yes. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay. That's the one thing I asked from you, the one thing. And now you're going to blame me forever.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Stop it will you? Stop it. If you don't want to move back to the States we won't. End of story. I'm just trying to find a way where I can be more of a consistent presence in his life, and ideally I'd like to do that as a family.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: ‘As a family?' Or what?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What the fuck does that mean? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  96.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I feel a passive aggressive threat in everything you say. Either do this, or I will resent you for the rest of our lives. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No? Am I Right? You know what? I'm sensing something... I think the problem is that you don't want me to have a more substantial job. On some level, you feel threatened by my achieving anything that could diminish your status in our relationship.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: My status in our relationship? I teach two courses a semester at the fucking American school. Ok wow, that's really some status.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Now I don't think it's any coincidence that you feel that way at the same time that I have a truly exciting job opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: This whole train of thought is complete horse shit and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I have a question for you. If we didn't have the girls, all our crap. Would we even still be together?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What? I mean you are the fucking Mayor of crazy town, do you know that? You are.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You know what I think? I think you need to move to Chicago. I think Henry needs you and I think I need to stay in Paris with the girls and take this job.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this, huh? That is a ridiculous idea. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  97.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like I'm gonna lose you and the girls? No. Why do you make everything so difficult?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Jesse, you're unhappy with me. You're blaming me for taking you away from your son.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: That is a completely irrational response to something I am just trying to feel my way through.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Listen, Jesse. We've just spent the last six weeks here and it's been great. You've been able to write everyday and the weather's been nice. But I didn't want to come to Greece originally.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: All right? There could be a revolution any second...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Don't.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: People eat a lot of feta and olive oil, they act all happy but they actually talk about how "angry" they are... and it confuses me and I don't know what's going to happen in the next few weeks.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, whoa. Let me tell you what's going to happen alright. The same thing that always happens: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Alright. You know what? I have had absolutely zero time for myself, I have ten thousand emails I have to answer that I didn't answer...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: And you think I don't? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  98.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I spend all day making dinner, wiping both you and your son's pee off the toilet seat, while you talk to your fellow novelists. Blah, blah, blah, you're a genius, blah, blah, blah, no, you're a genius. And the second we say goodbye to Henry, you suggest that maybe I should give up my dream job because you feel bad.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay, now it's your dream job?! This afternoon you weren't even sure you wanted it but now it's your dream job. Do you ever listen to yourself?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yes it is my dream job! Just because I have doubts doesn't mean I don't want it.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: All right? But what do you care? Every day you go on your two hour "contemplative" walk under the olive trees. Socrates... you should get a robe.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It's an hour.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, by the time you leave, and by the time you're actually with us again, two hours. You know, I could never do that. You're very good at taking care of yourself. I take care of myself, AND everything else. We're going somewhere, you pack your bag, I pack EVERYTHING else.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You would never let me pack the girls' shit. Never!

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Because there would be no shoes and plenty of dirty underwear.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: So says you. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  99.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I'm happy you have time to contemplate the universe and have existential problems because I don't - I barely have time to think. I work, I baby- sit, I work, I baby-sit. Jesse wanders off into the bathroom to take a pee.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Could you hold on a second? I just have to tune up the string section...

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You know what? The only time I get to think now, is when I take a shit at the office. I'm starting to associate thoughts with the smell of shit.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Well, that is a good line - I want to use that in a book someday.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I'm sure you will - and that'll be the best line in the book. She walks over and talks to him directly while he's in th bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And by the way, you may never, EVER, use me or anything I say or do in one of your fucking books again! And that goes for the girls, too. Jesse comes back out.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Well, A) You shouldn't have hooked up with a writer. B) You weren't in the last book or the one I'm writing now. C) I'm gonna write about whatever the fuck I want.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: As always, OUR life works for YOU.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No, no, no. Don't give me this put upon housewife bullshit. Okay this is not the 50's. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  100.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to ruin your perfect little narrative of oppression with the truth but I am the one who's at home everyday dealing with the bullshit cause you're at work until 6:30.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: 6 o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You take the girls to school, and I pick them up. That's fair, that's our deal. We live in Paris, France for chrissakes.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, and you remind me of it every single day.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I have orbited my entire life around you and you know it. So I am sorry if this Summer's vacation - and it is a vacation - because all I've seen you do is frolic in the sea and shove greek salad down your throat. Ok, but it is not indicative of you spending your life in some kind of domestic servitude.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You know what I love about men? They still believe in magic. Little fairies around who pick up their socks, little fairies unload the dishwasher, little fairies sunscreen the kids. Little fairies who make the fucking Greek salads that you eat like a pig.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay, listen to me, all right? You are great at taking care of us. You are. I mean you take care of the kids, you take care of your friends, you take care of the world. Alright? And you were like that before you were a mom and now its only magnified. But, and I've been telling you this for years - you gotta do a little bit better job taking care of yourself. Ok, you do. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  101.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay, stop patronizing me, all right? I'm the one at home every night at 6.00, not 6.30. I am reliable. Have you ever booked a baby sitter, ever, in your entire life? NO. What is the name of their pediatrician?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Stop quizzing me, all right? It's really fucking boring.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay. You know what? I'm at home every night and I make dinner, I give baths, and I read bedtime stories. Sometimes you're there, sometimes you're at a university event or a publicity tour. Ok? When you get "inspired" you keep on writing. I get inspired too sometimes, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You want to write? Great. Write.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, but you remember I used to sing and play guitar and write songs? I'd still like to do it. But I don't get to - there isn't time.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay. Well, first off, my writing isn't a hobby. Secondly, I wish you would find the time. You somehow manage to find the time to complain about 8 hours a day. I mean, I love the way you sing. Okay? I fucked up my whole life 'cause of the way you sing. Alright? If you took one eighth of the energy that you spend on bitching, whining and worrying... If you put that energy into playing scales, I mean you would be like fucking Django Reinhardt. Celine exits...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. All right. Whoops. You forgot your shoes. (sighs) Goddamn. Hell. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  102. And quickly re-enters.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You think you're winning?! (almost losing her temper ) Very few people realize what it is like for an active or passionate woman to have a child. Some friends told me, "you'll see, you'll want to throw them out the window." Okay, but the truth is I never wanted to hurt them once but I thought about ending it all for myself a hundred times. I was so confused, and you were always away on a stupid book tour or because of Henry's custody shit and I didn't want to be a burden. Now I know why Sylvia Plath put her head in a toaster.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It was an oven.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: (losing it) Don't play with words. You know what I mean - toaster, oven. Same thing. You know how many times I was alone with the girls crying with no clue what to do? Do you know the guilt a mother feels when she doesn't know what to do?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Do you think you have sole ownership of that feeling?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I don't think you understand, okay? (a beat) You know what my secret fear is? With every man? Is that they all want to turn me into a submissive housewife.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay, no one could EVER do that, all right? I promise, it would be easier to fit your head into a toaster than to turn you into anything submissive. The whole conversation has taken on a calmer tone. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  103.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I don't think I've recovered since giving birth. When they were born, I had no idea what to do. People expect women to have instinct that kicks in, like a female baboon. But I had no idea how to do anything. I loved them so much, and I was doing everything wrong. And you were away so often, calling me, asking me how my day went, and I couldn't even say it to you because I felt so ashamed for being so clueless.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Look, I think you did great.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No, you did. Well, you did a good job faking it, then.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I remember the only way I could get them to sleep was to drag that stupid double stroller down the stairs and walk them for hours and hours in the middle of the night, all the way to Pigalle and back. I almost got mugged once... I mean, the only reason why the guy didn't attack me was is that I looked so pathetic. The only upside of being over 35 is that you don't get raped as much. I read it - its true. Jesse laughs. The tone shifts.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus. (he takes her hand) Once I remember I was watching the twins on a trampoline, you know, and they looked so beautiful. And I was happy because they were happy, you know. One of them had this hula- hoop that she was using as a jump rope, but then the other one wanted it so they started fighting over it. All of a sudden I saw it all, this petty jealously and selfishness... I remember thinking: this is the natural (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  104.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: human state - always a little dissatisfied, perpetually discontented, you know? I mean, look at us, here we are, in a garden of Eden and we can't stop fighting.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I don't think there is one natural human state. The human state is multiple. If that's what you see when you're watching the girls play, that means you're depressed.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay. Maybe I am. Celine is slowly getting revved up again.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: When I see them fight, I see beautiful energy of going forward in life and not letting anyone step on them or take away what they want. I like it when they fight - it gives me hope for them.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Well that's because you see anger as a positive emotion, you know, and you only end up hurting yourself, your work, your kids, me.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: And you never get angry?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: When I do, I don't see it as a positive.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You know something? The way you write in your book, people come up to me and think I make love to some wildcat Henry Miller type... HA! You like to have sex the EXACT same way every time.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: When you got it, you got it.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Kissy, kissy. Titty, titty. PUSSY. (snoring) Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  105.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I'm a man of simple pleasures.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, very simple, and I've been meaning to tell you that lately. You're no Henry Miller, on any level. You know what, this room gives me the creeps, I was expecting something quaint, like the real Greece.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: This place is pretty real.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: What the hell are we doing here anyway? This is all too planned, like we're supposed to have this great evening. There's no room for spontaneity, it is all gone from our lives. It's stupid and it's not working...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay. Well, obviously, right?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Right, yeah ... and I curse Ariadni and that perv Stefanos for doing this. A couples massage - what the fuck is that? That sounds sleazy to me.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: We don't have to do it! Okay? C'mon, this place isn't so bad. I like hotel rooms... I think they're sexy.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know you do, Mr. Book Tour. Mr. Radisson Hilton. And I know that time when you were doing that reading in Washington, when your cell phone supposedly broke that night - how convenient. Swear on our kids that you didn't fuck that lady from the bookstore. Emily. Swear to me you didn't fuck that Emily girl. And I'm not jealous because I'm not the jealous type but I just wanna know, be a man and admit the truth. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  106.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I am giving you my whole life, okay? I've got nothing larger to give. I'm not giving it to anybody else. If you're looking for permission to disqualify me, I'm not going to give it to you. I love you and I'm NOT in conflict about it. But if what you want is a laundry list of all the things about you that piss me off, I could give it to you.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah - I want to hear.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay! Well, uh, let's start at number one - okay, number one, you're fuckin' nuts, alright? You are, good luck finding somebody else to put with your shit for more than like 6 months. But I accept the whole package, the crazy and the brilliant. I know you're not going to change, and I don't want you to. It's called accepting you for being you.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah okay, I asked you a question. If, while I was carrying the double stroller down the stairs and getting ass-raped in Pigalle, you fucked that little Emily Bronte girl?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Ok I don't know. Emily... what Emily? What are you even talking about?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: The one who wrote the nice emails about Dostoevsky? "Oh Jesse, you're so right, "The Grand Commander" is the deepest passage of all Russian literature."

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: If you're asking me if I'm committed to you, the girls, and the life we've built together, the answer is a resounding YES.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So you DID fuck her! Thank you very much. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  107.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Do I ever ask you about the time you went to go visit your old boyfriend after his mother died? No. You want to know why? Because I KNOW the way that your fucking French ass works, and I guarantee that you at least blew that guy, but I also know that you love me, okay? I'm okay with you being a complicated human being! I don't wanna live a boring life where two people own each other, where two people are institutionalized in a box that others created - because that is a bunch of stifling bullshit. Petrified, she exits. Jesse sits alone waiting for her to return. Enter Celine. She walks in, sets her room key down.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You know what's going on here? It's simple - I don't think I love you anymore. She exits. Jesse sits there, gazing from the cold cup of tea, to the door, to the full glasses of wine, to the rum empty bed. Celine doesn't come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesse finds Celine sitting near the same table where they saw the sunset earlier.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Miss?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk right now.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Are you by yourself? Are you waiting for somebody?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm by myself and happy to be. I'm an angry person and I hurt my kids, my work, and everyone I love.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, just my type. Jesse sits down right across from her. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  108.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm not in the mood - I came here to be alone.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, listen. I've just been checking you out from across the cafe and I don't want to make you uncomfortable, but you're by far the best looking woman in this place.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I'd love to buy you a drink, maybe talk to you, get to know you a little bit... you know. Are you here on business? Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ok.. You have a boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Not anymore.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Sorry to hear that. God, you want to talk about it?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I don't talk to strangers.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: But that's the thing, I'm not a stranger. No, we've met before... summer '94.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You are mistaking me for someone else.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No, we even fell in love.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Really? I vaguely remember someone sweet and romantic, who made me feel I wasn't alone anymore. Someone who had respect for who I was.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: That's me. I'm that guy. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  109.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Well, see, I know something about tonight that you don't know.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Really. What is that?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Something important. See, I know because I've actually already lived through this night.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I'm a time traveler.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I have a time machine up in my room. I've come to save you just like I said I would.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Save me from what?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Save you from being blinded by all the little bullshit of life.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It's not bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I assure you, that guy you vaguely remember, the sweet romantic one who you met on a train? That is me.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: That's you?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Guess I didn't recognize you... you look like shit. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  110.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What can I say? I mean, it's tough out there in time and space. You, on the other hand are even more beautiful than I remember.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Bullshit! Jesse, this is not a game. You get all cute, you get in my panties and the next thing I know, I'm buying peanut butter in Chicago. You're not going to make it better by some little pick up line.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I'm not trying to pick you up - no, no, you misunderstood me. I'm only here as a messenger. I've just traveled all the way from the future. I was just with your 82 year old self who gave me a letter to read to you. So here I am.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I'm still alive in my 80's?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: How's my French ass?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Nice. Really nice.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I don't care about the way I look.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Let's just say, there's even more of you to love. Okay, do you want me to read the letter to you?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Do I have a choice?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh sure, I mean, if you're not interested in what you have to say...

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, no, no. Read it. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  111.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay, here I go. Dear Celine, I'm writing to you from the other side of the woods. This letter is lighting a candle...

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay stop it. I would never write this - it's too flowery, "Other side of the woods," what fucking woods? What're you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: May I please continue?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I am sending you this young man. Yes, young - and he will be your escort. God knows, he has many problems and has struggled his whole life connecting and being present even with those he loves the most. And for that he is deeply sorry - but you are his only hope. Celine, my advice to you is this: you are entering the best years of your life. Looking back from where I sit now these middle years are only a little bit more difficult then when you were 12 and Mathieu and Vanessa danced all night to the Bee Gee's "How deep is your love." Celine, you will be fine. Your girls will grow up to become examples and icons of feminism.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Nice one.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, you know what I just noticed, there's a Post Script at the bottom, looks kind of important. Maybe I should just skip over the rest of this boring stuff and get to that?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, skip away. Please, skip away.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay. You sure? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  112.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay, all right, well.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: The boring stuff. Jesse scoots his chair closer to her.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Okay. (looks around, lowers his voice) Yeah, it's like financial tips, horoscopes, boring stuff. Okay, here it is... P.S. By the way, the best sex of my life happened one night in the Southern Peloponnese. Don't miss it. My whole sexual being went to a new, ground-breaking level.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Ground-breaking. Great.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I don't know what that means.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay, Jesse, can you stop this stupid game? We're not in one of your stories. Okay? Did you hear what I said to you back in the room? Did you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yes, I heard you - that you don't love me anymore. I figured you didn't mean it but if you did, then fuck it. You know something? You're just like the little girls and everybody else - you want to live in some fairy tale. I'm just trying to make things better here. I tell you I love you unconditionally, I tell you that you're beautiful, I tell you that your ass looks great when you're 80. I'm trying to make you laugh. I put up with plenty of your shit, and if you think I'm just some dog who's gonna keep coming back then, you're wrong. But if you want true love - this is it. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  113.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is real life. It's not perfect, but it's real. And if you can't see it, then you're blind, alright? I give up. Jesse crumples up the napkin/letter he was reading from a tosses it on the table. What follows is a lengthy silent sequence where they just sort of stare at each other, seemingly going through everything past and present.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So what about this time machine?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: How does it work?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Well... it's complicated.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Am I going to have to get naked to operate it? Jesse's mood shifts, and the camera starts to slowly pull away from them as they continue talking.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, actually. Yeah, it's been a real issue, you know, clothes don't travel well through the whole space- time continuum.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: (bimbo voice) Wow. You're so smart.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Space-time...?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Continuum.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: ‘Continuum. '

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  114.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You know, there's something I have been thinking about, about your letter. You mention something about the southern Peloponesse? We're in the southern Peloponesse.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Do you think it could be tonight that you're still talking about in your 80s?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Well, it must have been one hell of a night we're about to have. The camera has now pulled far away and the conversation h become inaudible. We leave them as just another couple sitting and talking at a table on a beautiful night on th coast of Greece.

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT
